The morning mist clung to the hills surrounding Epsom like a shroud, and Jake Meridian could feel the disturbance in the Force before he even opened his eyes. Something was different today, though he couldn't quite place what it was. Rolling out of his narrow bed in the converted stable loft that served as his modest dwelling, he stretched his lean frame and gazed out through the diamond-paned window at the sprawling gardens below.

For three years now, Jake had lived in relative obscurity here in Surrey, far from the chaos that had consumed the galaxy. The small estate he called home belonged to an elderly widow named Mrs. Pemberton, who had taken him in without question when he'd arrived with nothing but the clothes on his back and a carefully concealed lightsaber. She never asked about his past, and he never volunteered information about the fallen Jedi Order or the Empire's relentless hunt for survivors like himself.

The gardens were Mrs. Pemberton's pride and joy, though her arthritis had made it increasingly difficult for her to maintain them properly. That's where Maya came in. Jake's breath caught slightly as he spotted her familiar figure moving between the rose bushes, her dark hair pulled back in a practical ponytail as she worked. She'd been the estate's gardener for just over a year now, and Jake had spent most of that time trying to convince himself that his growing feelings for her were nothing more than loneliness manifesting itself inappropriately.

It wasn't working very well.

Maya Thornfield had arrived at the estate on a rainy Tuesday morning, her ancient Land Rover packed with tools and an impressive collection of seedlings. She was twenty-six, two years younger than Jake, with callused hands that spoke of honest work and green eyes that seemed to see straight through his carefully constructed facade. Within weeks, she had transformed the neglected flower beds into something approaching their former glory, coaxing life from soil that had seemed barren and hopeless.

Jake pulled on his worn jeans and a faded t-shirt, running his fingers through his unruly brown hair before making his way downstairs. Mrs. Pemberton was already in the kitchen, humming tunelessly as she prepared her morning tea. At seventy-eight, she moved with the deliberate care of someone who had learned not to take physical stability for granted, but her mind remained sharp as ever.

"Morning, dear," she said without turning around. "Maya's been out there since dawn. That girl works too hard."

"Good morning, Mrs. P." Jake accepted the mug of coffee she handed him gratefully. "I'll take her some tea in a bit."

The older woman gave him a knowing look. "Will you now? How thoughtful of you."

Jake felt heat rise in his cheeks. His feelings for Maya weren't exactly subtle, despite his best efforts. Even without the Force, it would have been obvious to anyone paying attention. Mrs. Pemberton was definitely paying attention.

"She needs to stay hydrated," he mumbled into his coffee mug.

"Of course she does." Mrs. Pemberton's eyes twinkled with amusement. "You know, Jake, there's nothing wrong with admitting you fancy someone. You're both adults, and you're both single. Unless there's something you haven't told me about your mysterious past?"

There were many things Jake hadn't told her about his mysterious past, but none of them involved romantic entanglements. The Jedi Order had fallen before he'd had much chance to grapple with questions of love and attachment, though he suspected his old Master would have had strong opinions on the subject. Master Kellan had been traditional in his interpretation of the Jedi Code, viewing emotional attachments as pathways to the dark side.

But Master Kellan was dead now, cut down during Order 66 along with so many others. The Code felt like ancient history, a relic of a time when there had been thousands of Jedi to uphold its principles. Now there was just Jake, hiding in an English garden and falling helplessly in love with a woman who thought he was nothing more than Mrs. Pemberton's odd handyman.

"Nothing like that," he said finally. "I just... it's complicated."

"Most worthwhile things are." Mrs. Pemberton patted his shoulder gently. "But don't let complicated become an excuse for cowardice, dear. Life's too short and unpredictable for that."

Jake nodded, though he wasn't sure he agreed. In his experience, life was often too long and too predictable, especially when you were trying to avoid the attention of Imperial forces. Still, he found himself preparing a tray with tea and biscuits for Maya, telling himself it was simple courtesy rather than an excuse to spend time with her.

The morning air was crisp with the promise of autumn as Jake made his way through the garden paths. Maya was kneeling beside a bed of late-blooming chrysanthemums, carefully removing spent flowers with a pair of small pruning shears. She looked up as he approached, pushing a strand of hair away from her face with the back of her gardening glove.

"You're an angel," she said, accepting the steaming mug gratefully. "I was just thinking I could murder a cup of tea."

"Mrs. P's orders," Jake lied easily. "She thinks you work too hard."

"Mrs. P is probably right." Maya settled back on her heels, cradling the mug in both hands. "But these flowers won't deadhead themselves, and we're supposed to get frost next week. I want to give them every chance to keep blooming."

Jake crouched down beside her, close enough to catch the faint scent of her shampoo mixed with earth and green growing things. "Need help?"

"Always." Maya handed him a spare pair of shears. "Just cut above the next set of healthy leaves. These chrysanthemums can be quite prolific if you treat them right."

They worked in comfortable silence for a while, their hands occasionally brushing as they reached for the same stem. Jake found himself hyperaware of her presence beside him, the quiet concentration on her face as she worked, the way she unconsciously bit her lower lip when she encountered a particularly stubborn flower. Through the Force, he could sense her contentment, the deep satisfaction she found in nurturing growing things.

It was one of the things he loved most about her, though he'd never admitted it aloud. Maya had a gift for bringing life and beauty to neglected spaces. She saw potential where others saw only decay, and she wasn't afraid of the patient work required to realize that potential. In many ways, she reminded Jake of the best aspects of the Jedi philosophy he'd been raised with, though she'd never held a lightsaber or meditated on the nature of the Force.

"Jake?" Maya's voice interrupted his reverie. "Can I ask you something?"

"Of course."

"Where did you learn to garden? I mean, you're quite good at this, but you never talk about where you picked it up."

Jake's hands stilled on the chrysanthemum stems. It was a reasonable question, the sort of casual inquiry that arose naturally between people who worked closely together. The problem was that his gardening skills, like most of his practical knowledge, came from his Jedi training. The Temple on Coruscant had maintained extensive gardens, and young Padawans were expected to spend time learning to cultivate and care for living things. Master Kellan had always said that understanding life was essential to understanding the Force.

"My... my father taught me," he said finally, which wasn't entirely untrue. The Jedi who had raised him had been the closest thing to a father he'd ever known. "He believed that working with plants taught patience and respect for living things."

"He sounds like a wise man." Maya resumed her pruning. "Is he still alive?"

The familiar ache of loss tightened in Jake's chest. "No. He died several years ago."

"I'm sorry." Maya's voice was soft with genuine sympathy. "You don't talk about your family much."

"There isn't much to say. It's just me now."

Maya glanced at him sideways, and Jake sensed her curiosity warring with respect for his obvious reluctance to discuss his past. It was a dance they'd performed many times over the past year, Maya gently probing and Jake deflecting with vague half-truths that satisfied her surface curiosity without revealing anything meaningful about who he really was or where he'd come from.He hated lying to her, but the alternative was unthinkable. How could he possibly explain that he was a survivor of a religious order that most people now believed had been a corrupt institution justly destroyed by the Empire? How could he tell her that he carried a weapon capable of cutting through steel, that he could move objects with his mind, that he sometimes woke in the night with visions of distant suffering echoing through the Force? Maya lived in a world of soil and seasons, of practical problems with practical solutions. The galaxy's larger conflicts seemed mercifully distant from this quiet corner of Surrey, and Jake was determined to keep it that way.

"We all have our secrets, I suppose," Maya said eventually, her tone carefully neutral. She moved to the next cluster of flowers, and Jake followed, grateful that she wasn't pressing the issue. "Mrs. Pemberton mentioned that you help her with repairs around the estate. Are you handy with mechanical things too?"

Jake nodded, relieved by the change of subject. "I can usually figure out what's wrong with most machinery. It's just a matter of understanding how the pieces fit together." This was true enough, though he carefully didn't mention that the Force often guided his understanding, showing him the flow of energy through circuits and gears in ways that purely technical training never could have achieved.

"Well, if you ever get tired of fixing gutters and painting fences, I could use someone to look at the mower. It's been making terrible noises, and I'm afraid it's going to give up the ghost entirely." Maya stood and stretched, brushing dirt from the knees of her practical canvas trousers. "Though I suppose you'd rather not spend your free time doing more manual labor."

"I don't mind," Jake said quickly. "I mean, I enjoy working with my hands. And it's not as if I have pressing social obligations." The last part came out more bitter than he'd intended, and Maya raised an eyebrow at his tone.

"You could, you know. Have social obligations. There's a perfectly decent pub in the village, and Mrs. Pemberton says the local amateur dramatics society is always looking for new members." Maya's green eyes held a hint of challenge. "Unless you're one of those mysterious loners who's too good for small-town entertainment."

Jake felt a smile tug at the corners of his mouth despite himself. Maya had a talent for gentle teasing that somehow managed to be affectionate rather than cruel. It was another thing he'd added to his growing list of reasons why he was falling in love with her, though he tried not to dwell on that particular revelation too closely.

"I'm not too good for anything," he said. "I just prefer quiet evenings. All that socializing can be... overwhelming." This was perhaps the most honest thing he'd said to her in months. Large crowds made him nervous in ways that had nothing to do with shyness and everything to do with the increased chance of recognition by Imperial agents or bounty hunters. Even in peaceful Surrey, Jake had never quite managed to shake the hypervigilance that had kept him alive for three years of hiding.

"Fair enough," Maya said, though something in her expression suggested she wasn't entirely satisfied with his explanation. "But you might consider giving the pub a try sometime. The Lamb and Flag does excellent fish and chips on Fridays, and the locals are friendly enough once they get used to you. You've been here three years, Jake. At some point, you're going to have to decide whether you're hiding from something or just hiding from life."

The observation hit uncomfortably close to home, and Jake found himself looking away from Maya's perceptive gaze. She was right, of course, though not in the way she imagined. He was hiding from something very specific and very dangerous, but somewhere along the way, that necessary caution had expanded into a more general withdrawal from human connection. It was safer to keep people at arm's length, to maintain the polite distance that would allow him to disappear quickly if the need arose.

But Maya was making it increasingly difficult to maintain that distance. She had a way of slipping past his defenses with casual observations and genuine interest in his wellbeing. She remembered things he mentioned in passing, brought him soup when he'd been fighting off a cold, and had somehow convinced Mrs. Pemberton to let her plant a small herb garden outside his loft window because she'd noticed how much he enjoyed cooking. These small kindnesses accumulated like interest, creating a debt of affection that Jake wasn't sure he could repay without compromising the careful anonymity that had kept him safe.

"Maybe you're right," he said finally, which was about as much of a concession as he was prepared to make. "I'll think about it."

Maya's smile was warm and encouraging, and Jake felt something flutter in his chest that had nothing to do with the Force and everything to do with the way the morning light caught the gold flecks in her green eyes. He was in serious trouble, he realized, and not the sort that could be solved with a lightsaber or a quick escape to the next system. This was the kind of trouble that required difficult choices and emotional honesty, two things that Jake had been avoiding with determined consistency since arriving at Mrs. Pemberton's estate.

The sound of tires on gravel interrupted his brooding, and both Jake and Maya turned toward the front of the house where an unfamiliar black sedan was pulling up the circular drive. Jake's hand moved instinctively toward where his lightsaber would have hung if he'd been wearing it, then forced himself to relax. Visitors weren't necessarily threats, despite what three years of paranoia had trained him to believe.

"Expecting someone?" Maya asked Mrs. Pemberton, who had emerged from the house to greet the new arrivals.

"Not that I recall," the elderly woman replied, though her tone was curious rather than concerned. "Perhaps it's someone inquiring about the cottage rental advertisement."

Jake tensed. Mrs. Pemberton had mentioned placing an advertisement for the small guest cottage at the far end of the property, hoping to generate a bit of additional income now that the estate's maintenance costs were rising. The idea of strangers living so close to his hiding place made Jake profoundly uncomfortable, but he could hardly object without explaining why he was so concerned about privacy and security.

Two men emerged from the sedan, both wearing dark suits that seemed impractical for the rural Surrey setting. They moved with the kind of controlled precision that Jake recognized from his years of military training, their eyes constantly scanning their surroundings in a way that suggested professional paranoia rather than casual curiosity. Jake's mouth went dry as he recognized the signs of trained operatives, though he couldn't immediately determine whether they were Imperial agents, bounty hunters, or representatives of some other organization entirely.

"Mrs. Pemberton?" The taller of the two men approached with a polite smile that didn't quite reach his eyes. "I'm Agent Morrison from the Ministry of Defence. This is my colleague, Agent Webb. We were wondering if we might have a word with you about a security matter."**Chapter 2**

The blood in Jake's veins turned to ice water as the word 'security' hung in the morning air like a death sentence. Every instinct screamed at him to run, to grab his lightsaber from its hiding place and disappear into the Surrey countryside before these agents could complete whatever mission had brought them to Mrs. Pemberton's peaceful estate. His hand trembled slightly as he forced himself to continue deadheading chrysanthemums, maintaining the facade of a simple gardener's assistant while his mind raced through escape routes and contingency plans he'd hoped never to use.

Maya seemed to sense his sudden tension, glancing at him with a puzzled frown before turning her attention back to the unfolding scene near the house. Mrs. Pemberton appeared unruffled by the unexpected visit, inviting the agents inside with the same gracious hospitality she showed to everyone who crossed her threshold. Jake watched helplessly as the three figures disappeared through the front door, leaving him alone in the garden with Maya and a growing sense of impending doom.

"That was odd," Maya observed, settling back on her heels beside the flower bed. "Ministry of Defence agents don't usually make house calls in Surrey, do they? Mrs. P isn't exactly the sort of person you'd expect to be involved in matters of national security." She paused, studying Jake's face with the same careful attention she gave to ailing plants. "You've gone completely white. Are you feeling alright?"

Jake realized he was hyperventilating and forced himself to take slow, measured breaths. Through the Force, he could sense the agents' presence inside the house like cold spots in the warm tapestry of the estate's usual emotional landscape. They radiated the kind of controlled aggression that spoke of men accustomed to violence, though their intentions remained frustratingly opaque. He couldn't determine whether they were specifically hunting for him or if this visit was related to some other matter entirely, but either way, his carefully constructed sanctuary was now compromised.

"I'm fine," he managed, though his voice sounded strained even to his own ears. "Just surprised, I suppose. You don't expect government agents to show up at a quiet country estate." He stood abruptly, scattering chrysanthemum clippings from his lap. "I should check on Mrs. P. Make sure she doesn't need anything."

Maya caught his wrist as he started toward the house, her gardening glove warm against his skin. "Jake, what aren't you telling me? You look like you've seen a ghost, and don't say it's just surprise. I've known you for over a year, and I've never seen you react like this to anything." Her green eyes searched his face with uncomfortable intensity. "Are you in some kind of trouble?"

The question hung between them like a bridge Jake could either cross or burn, and for a moment he was tempted to tell her everything. The loneliness of carrying his secrets alone had been wearing on him more heavily than he'd realized, and the genuine concern in Maya's voice made him want to trust her with truths he'd never spoken aloud. She deserved better than the careful lies he'd been feeding her, deserved to know that the man she'd been working beside for months was not the simple handyman he pretended to be.

But the sound of voices from the house reminded him sharply of the dangers such honesty would bring. If these agents were indeed hunting for surviving Jedi, then Maya's ignorance was her protection. The Empire had demonstrated repeatedly that it was willing to eliminate anyone who aided or harbored fugitives from Imperial justice, and Jake would not make Maya a target through misguided confessions. Better to maintain the deception that kept her safe, even if it meant continuing to lie to the woman he was falling in love with.

"Everyone has things in their past they'd rather not discuss," he said carefully, gently extracting his wrist from her grip. "I'm just not fond of authority figures asking questions. Bad experiences with bureaucracy." It was a weak explanation, but it was all he could offer without revealing more than was safe. "I'll be back in a few minutes."

Maya's expression suggested she wasn't satisfied with his evasion, but she nodded reluctantly and returned to her pruning. Jake could feel her worried gaze following him as he made his way toward the house, moving with what he hoped appeared to be casual concern rather than desperate panic. Through the diamond-paned windows of the sitting room, he could see Mrs. Pemberton seated in her favorite armchair while the two agents occupied the sofa across from her, their postures suggesting polite interrogation rather than social conversation.

Jake positioned himself near the kitchen window that looked into the sitting room, close enough to overhear the conversation without being obvious about his eavesdropping. Mrs. Pemberton was speaking in her usual calm, measured tones, though Jake could detect a slight stiffness in her manner that suggested she was not entirely comfortable with her visitors.

"As I mentioned, gentlemen, my late husband did serve in the Royal Navy, but that was decades ago. I can't imagine what relevance his service record might have to current security concerns." Mrs. Pemberton's voice carried the faint edge of aristocratic authority that she rarely displayed but which reminded listeners that she had not always been a country widow of modest means. "He passed away eight years ago, and took most of his military memories with him."

Agent Morrison consulted a small notebook, his movements precise and economical. "We're actually more interested in your current household, Mrs. Pemberton. Our records indicate that you've taken in a lodger in recent years, a young man named Jake Meridian. We'd very much like to speak with him about a matter of mutual interest."

Jake's blood turned to ice as his assumed name left the agent's lips. The false identity he'd constructed so carefully had somehow attracted official attention, which meant either his documentation was less perfect than he'd believed or someone had connected him to his Jedi past despite his precautions. Either possibility represented a catastrophic failure of the security measures that had kept him alive for three years of hiding.

Mrs. Pemberton's response was delayed by just long enough to suggest she was choosing her words carefully. "Jake is indeed staying in the converted stable loft, and has been for some time. He's been tremendously helpful with maintenance around the estate, though I know very little about his background. He's quite private about personal matters." She paused, and Jake could practically hear her internal debate about how much information to volunteer. "May I ask what sort of mutual interest you're referring to? Jake seems like a perfectly ordinary young man to me."

Agent Webb leaned forward slightly, his voice taking on a tone of practiced reassurance. "Nothing alarming, I assure you. We simply have reason to believe that Mr. Meridian might possess information relevant to an ongoing investigation. Historical information, you might say, about events that occurred several years ago. We're hoping he might be willing to assist with our inquiries."

The euphemistic language did nothing to disguise the threat implicit in the agents' words, and Jake felt the familiar weight of the Force pressing against his consciousness as his emotional state became increasingly unstable. Somewhere in the garden behind him, a ceramic flowerpot cracked audibly, though he hoped the sound was too distant for the agents to notice. He needed to get control of himself before his unconscious use of the Force provided these men with exactly the evidence they were seeking.

Mrs. Pemberton's voice took on a protective edge that made Jake's chest tighten with unexpected emotion. "I see. And if Jake chooses not to assist with these inquiries of yours? I assume his cooperation is voluntary?" The question carried implications that were not lost on anyone present, and Jake realized with a mixture of gratitude and alarm that Mrs. Pemberton understood more about the nature of this visit than she was letting on.

"Of course," Agent Morrison replied smoothly, though his tone suggested that voluntary cooperation was strongly preferred over the alternatives. "We're simply hoping to have a conversation with him. Perhaps you could let him know that we stopped by? We'll be staying at the Lamb and Flag in the village for the next few days, in case he decides he'd like to speak with us."

Jake felt his world shifting beneath his feet as the agents rose to leave, their polite farewells masking what amounted to a veiled ultimatum. They knew where he lived, they knew his assumed identity, and they would be waiting in the village for him to either surrender voluntarily or force them to take more direct action. Either way, his time at Mrs. Pemberton's estate was over, and the life he'd built here was about to collapse around him.

He moved quickly away from the window as footsteps approached the front door, retreating toward the garden where Maya was still working among the flowers. She looked up as he rejoined her, her expression immediately concerned as she took in what must have been his obvious distress.

"What did they want?" she asked quietly, setting down her pruning shears and giving him her full attention. "And don't tell me it was routine government business, because you look like someone just walked over your grave."

Jake sank down beside her on the grass, his legs suddenly unsteady. Through the Force, he could sense the agents' departure, their black sedan pulling away from the estate with measured deliberation. They weren't in any hurry because they knew he had nowhere to run, at least not without abandoning everything and everyone he'd come to care about in Surrey. It was a masterfully executed psychological trap, offering him just enough time to contemplate what he would be losing before forcing him to make an impossible choice.

"They were asking about me," he said finally, the words feeling like broken glass in his throat. "They want to talk to me about something that happened years ago, before I came here. They're staying at the pub in the village." He met Maya's eyes, trying to memorize the way the morning light brought out the gold flecks in the green. "I think I'm going to have to leave."

Maya's face went through several expressions in quick succession - confusion, concern, and finally a kind of hurt realization. "Leave? Just like that? Because some government agents want to ask you questions?" She reached for his hand, her fingers intertwining with his despite the dirt under both their nails. "Jake, whatever happened in your past, surely it can't be so bad that you have to run away from it forever. Maybe if you just talked to them, explained your side of things..."

The innocent faith in her voice nearly broke Jake's heart. Maya lived in a world where problems could be solved through honest communication and good intentions, where authority figures were generally trustworthy and the system ultimately fair. She had no frame of reference for the kind of systematic persecution that had driven Jake into hiding, no understanding of how quickly cooperation with the wrong people could lead to imprisonment or death.

"It's not that simple," he said, his thumb tracing across her knuckles in what might be the last intimate gesture he'd ever share with her. "Some things can't be explained or reasoned away. Some people won't listen to explanations even if you offer them." He paused, struggling with how much truth he could afford to share. "I've been running from this for a long time, Maya. I thought I could stop running, thought I could build something here, but I was fooling myself."

Maya's grip on his hand tightened, and Jake could sense her confusion and growing fear through their physical connection. She was beginning to understand that this was not a minor crisis that could be resolved with a difficult conversation, but rather something that threatened to tear away the life they'd both been building on the estate.

"What did you do?" she asked quietly, and Jake heard no judgment in the question, only a desperate need to understand. "What could possibly be so terrible that you've spent years hiding from it?"

Jake opened his mouth to answer, then closed it again as he realized there were no words that could bridge the gap between Maya's world and his own. How could he explain that he had been trained from childhood to serve a cause that the galaxy now viewed as treasonous? How could he make her understand that his very existence was considered a threat to Imperial stability, that the peaceful life they'd shared was built on foundations of deception and constant vigilance?

The sound of Mrs. Pemberton's voice calling from the house provided a merciful interruption, though Jake suspected the elderly woman's timing was not entirely coincidental. She had probably been watching from the windows, giving him and Maya privacy for their conversation while ensuring she could intervene before things became too difficult to manage.

"I should go talk to her," Jake said, reluctantly releasing Maya's hand and getting to his feet. "She deserves to know what's happening, and I need to make sure she'll be safe after I'm gone." He looked down at Maya, who was still kneeling among the chrysanthemums with tears threatening at the corners of her eyes. "We'll talk more later, I promise. But right now I need to figure out how to protect the people I care about."

Maya nodded wordlessly, and Jake could feel her watching him as he walked back toward the house. Mrs. Pemberton was waiting in the kitchen, her face grave but unsurprised by the turn of events. She gestured for him to sit at the small table where they'd shared so many morning conversations over the past three years, then put the kettle on for tea with the automatic motions of someone who had weathered many crises with the aid of proper refreshments.

"Those men weren't really from the Ministry of Defence," she said without preamble, settling into the chair across from him. "Oh, they had the right credentials and the proper manner, but there was something off about them. Too smooth, too rehearsed. Like actors playing roles they'd memorized but not internalized." She studied Jake's face with the same sharp intelligence that had first convinced him she could be trusted. "The question is, who are they really, and what do they want with my Jake?"

The possessive pronoun hit Jake harder than he'd expected, and he felt his throat tighten with emotion. Mrs. Pemberton had given him more than just shelter over the past three years; she had given him a sense of belonging that he hadn't experienced since the fall of the Jedi Temple. The idea of repaying her kindness by bringing danger to her doorstep was almost unbearable.

"They're probably exactly who they claim to be," he said carefully. "Government agents investigating something from my past. The problem is that what they're investigating isn't something I can discuss openly, and cooperation with their inquiry would put both of us in danger." He met her eyes, trying to convey sincerity without revealing specifics. "I never meant for this to follow me here, Mrs. P. I thought I'd been careful enough, but apparently I was wrong."

Mrs. Pemberton poured boiling water into the teapot and let it steep, her movements deliberate and calming. "You know, my dear, I may be an old woman living quietly in the country, but I'm not entirely naive about the way the world works. I've lived through wars and political upheavals, seen governments rise and fall, watched good people forced to make impossible choices." She reached across the table and patted his hand gently. "I knew from the beginning that you were running from something. The question was whether you were running from something you'd done or something that had been done to you."

Jake stared at her in surprise, realizing that his carefully maintained facade had been far less convincing than he'd believed. "And what conclusion did you reach?"

"That you're a good man who's been hurt by circumstances beyond his control," Mrs. Pemberton replied without hesitation. "You've been nothing but helpful and respectful in the time you've lived here, Jake. You've treated Maya with genuine kindness, you've cared for this estate as if it were your own, and you've given an old woman companionship when she needed it most. Whatever happened in your past, it hasn't made you into someone I need to fear or distrust."

The unconditional acceptance in her voice nearly undid Jake's composure entirely. He'd spent so long believing that his Jedi training made him fundamentally different from ordinary people, that the power he carried made him dangerous and unwelcome in normal society. Mrs. Pemberton's faith in his character challenged that assumption in ways that were both comforting and deeply unsettling.

"You might feel differently if you knew the whole truth," he said quietly. "There are things about me that most people would find... difficult to accept."

Mrs. Pemberton smiled and poured tea into two delicate china cups, adding milk and sugar with practiced ease. "My dear boy, I'm seventy-eight years old. I've learned that most people are far more complex and surprising than they appear on the surface. I've also learned that a person's actions matter more than their origins or their past mistakes." She handed him a cup of tea, the familiar ritual oddly soothing despite the circumstances. "Now, what are we going to do about these agents who are so interested in speaking with you?"

Jake sipped his tea, buying time while he considered his extremely limited options. Running was the obvious choice, the strategy that had kept him alive for three years of hiding. He could pack his few belongings, retrieve his lightsaber from its hiding place, and disappear before dawn, leaving behind nothing but a note of apology and explanation. By the time the agents realized he was gone, he could be halfway to Scotland or Wales, beginning the process of establishing yet another false identity in yet another anonymous location.

But the thought of leaving Mrs. Pemberton and Maya to deal with the aftermath of his disappearance made him feel sick. The agents would undoubtedly question both women extensively, searching for clues about his destination or contacts who might be harboring him. Even if they eventually concluded that neither woman had been complicit in his escape, the experience would be traumatic and potentially dangerous. Worse, his sudden departure would shatter the trust and affection that had grown between him and the two people he'd come to love most in this new life.

The alternative was to stay and face whatever consequences these agents represented, but that path seemed to lead inevitably toward capture, imprisonment, or death. Jake had no illusions about the Empire's treatment of surviving Jedi, and he doubted that these particular agents were interested in a peaceful resolution to their inquiry. They had found him despite his precautions, which suggested resources and determination that would not be easily evaded.

"I don't know," he admitted, setting down his teacup with hands that trembled slightly. "Running seems cowardly, but staying might put you and Maya in danger. I never wanted either of you to be involved in this, Mrs. P. You've both been so good to me, and now I'm going to repay that kindness by bringing trouble to your door."

Mrs. Pemberton reached across the table and covered his hand with hers, her grip surprisingly strong for someone her age. "Jake, listen to me very carefully. You are not responsible for other people's actions, only your own. If these agents choose to threaten or harass innocent people, that's a reflection of their character, not yours. Don't let guilt over hypothetical consequences prevent you from making the choice that's right for you."

Her words carried the weight of hard-won wisdom, and Jake found himself wondering what experiences had taught her such lessons. There were depths to Mrs. Pemberton that he'd never fully explored, hints of a past that involved more than the quiet domesticity he'd observed. Perhaps everyone was carrying secrets, he reflected, and his were simply more dramatic than most.

"What would you do?" he asked, genuinely curious about her perspective. "If you were in my position, facing a choice between running and staying to confront something you weren't sure you could survive?"

Mrs. Pemberton was quiet for a long moment, her eyes distant as she considered the question. When she spoke, her voice carried a note of melancholy that Jake had never heard before. "I spent many years running from difficult truths, my dear. Not literally, as you have, but emotionally. I convinced myself that avoiding confrontation was the same as maintaining peace, that keeping secrets was the same as protecting the people I loved." She met his eyes with an intensity that was almost uncomfortable. "It took me far too long to learn that running away doesn't make problems disappear. It only ensures that you'll face them alone, without the support of people who care about you."

The observation struck Jake with uncomfortable accuracy, highlighting the isolation that had defined his life since the fall of the Jedi Order. He had indeed been facing his problems alone, convinced that solitude was the price of keeping others safe. But Mrs. Pemberton was suggesting that this isolation might be a choice rather than a necessity, that there might be alternatives to the stark binary of complete secrecy or total revelation.

"What are you suggesting?" he asked, though he suspected he already knew the answer.

"Well then," Mrs. Pemberton said, her aristocratic accent carrying decades of experience with impossible situations and the decisions they demanded from ordinary people caught in extraordinary circumstances, "it appears we're all going on an adventure together. I do hope your people have prepared accommodations suitable for elderly ladies with strong opinions about proper tea and comfortable seating arrangements. I'm rather too old to sleep on the ground or subsist entirely on military rations, regardless of how urgent our strategic situation might become." Her dry humor provided a moment of levity that helped cut through the tension and fear that had been building as their situation grew increasingly desperate with each passing moment.

Kira's expression shifted from tactical calculation to something approaching amusement as she processed Mrs. Pemberton's response to their crisis, the elderly woman's calm acceptance of galactic conflicts and evacuation procedures suggesting backgrounds and experiences that went far beyond the peaceful domesticity that had characterized Jake's understanding of her identity. Through the Force, Jake could sense Kira's growing respect for the two women who had chosen to share his exile and were now prepared to share the dangers that came with active resistance to Imperial authority. Their courage in the face of overwhelming uncertainty was the kind of inspiration that had once motivated entire star systems to rise against impossible odds, ordinary people becoming extraordinary through their refusal to abandon principles or people they held dear.

The first TIE fighter appeared over the tree line like a harbinger of destruction, its distinctive scream cutting through the sounds of ground combat as it prepared to demonstrate the overwhelming technological superiority that had made Imperial forces feared throughout the galaxy. Jake realized that their window for successful evacuation was closing with terrifying speed, the approaching aerial assault representing a level of destructive capability that would reduce the entire estate to smoking ruins within minutes of engagement. The beautiful gardens where he had worked alongside Maya for over a year, the peaceful rooms where he had shared countless conversations with Mrs. Pemberton, the quiet domesticity that had given his life meaning for the first time since the fall of the Jedi Temple—all of it would soon be nothing more than memory and regret if they could not reach the extraction vehicles before Imperial doctrine replaced tactical precision with overwhelming destructive force.

Kira gestured sharply toward her team's vehicles, her movements carrying the urgent authority of someone accustomed to coordinating evacuations under extreme duress and impossible time constraints. The rescue operatives were already withdrawing from their forward positions, their covering fire designed to provide concealment for the evacuation rather than achieve tactical victory against superior Imperial forces. Jake could sense their professional competence through the Force, the calm efficiency of people who had learned to balance heroism with survival instincts honed through years of fighting against overwhelming odds. These were not fanatics willing to die uselessly for symbolic victories, but experienced operatives who understood that successful resistance required living to fight another day rather than achieving glorious martyrdom in hopeless causes.

Maya took Jake's hand with the kind of grip that suggested she was prepared to follow him into whatever unknown dangers lay beyond the familiar boundaries of the estate that had been their shared home for so many peaceful months. Her touch carried love and trust that transcended understanding, faith in his character and judgment that went far beyond rational calculation of risks and benefits. Through their physical connection, Jake could feel her fear and excitement intermingling in ways that reminded him of everything worth fighting for in a galaxy that too often seemed determined to crush individual bonds of affection in favor of institutional loyalty and systematic control. Her willingness to abandon everything familiar for an uncertain future at his side was both humbling and empowering, a reminder that love could be a source of incredible strength rather than mere vulnerability to be exploited by enemies.

Mrs. Pemberton moved with surprising agility as they began their withdrawal toward the extraction vehicles, her years of apparent peaceful retirement having done little to diminish the survival instincts that had carried her through decades of political upheaval and personal loss. Jake realized that he had underestimated her capabilities just as thoroughly as he had underestimated Maya's courage, viewing both women through the lens of protective condescension rather than recognizing them as individuals fully capable of making informed decisions about risk and sacrifice. Their willingness to join his exile from peaceful domesticity to active resistance was not born of ignorance or manipulation, but of conscious choice to prioritize relationships and principles over personal safety and comfortable predictability.

The estate grounds that had been Jake's sanctuary for three years were rapidly becoming a battlefield that would soon be completely uninhabitable, transformed from peaceful domesticity into smoking ruins by the collision of forces larger than individual choice or personal desire. As they ran toward the extraction vehicles through gardens that Maya had tended with such loving care, Jake felt the weight of everything they were losing pressed down on him like a physical force. The quiet conversations over morning tea, the shared work in flower beds and vegetable plots, the simple pleasure of watching seasons change without the constant threat of discovery and violence—all of it was ending as abruptly as it had begun, swept away by the galaxy's relentless demand for choosing sides in conflicts that offered no neutral ground for people who simply wanted to live in peace.

But as he felt Maya's hand in his and sensed Mrs. Pemberton's determined presence beside them, Jake realized that perhaps he was not losing everything after all, but rather discovering what was truly essential and what could be rebuilt anywhere as long as the people he loved were willing to share whatever uncertain future awaited them beyond the burning estate. The Force whispered promises of new possibilities and different kinds of peace, suggesting that sanctuary might be found not in geographical isolation but in the bonds of trust and affection that connected hearts across the vastness of space and time. Their flight from the only home he had known since Order 66 was not merely escape but transformation, the beginning of something new rather than simply the end of something precious.

The morning mist clung to the hills surrounding Epsom like a shroud, and Jake Meridian could feel the disturbance in the Force before he even opened his eyes. Something was different today, though he couldn't quite place what it was. Rolling out of his narrow bed in the converted stable loft that served as his modest dwelling, he stretched his lean frame and gazed out through the diamond-paned window at the sprawling gardens below.

For three years now, Jake had lived in relative obscurity here in Surrey, far from the chaos that had consumed the galaxy. The small estate he called home belonged to an elderly widow named Mrs. Pemberton, who had taken him in without question when he'd arrived with nothing but the clothes on his back and a carefully concealed lightsaber. She never asked about his past, and he never volunteered information about the fallen Jedi Order or the Empire's relentless hunt for survivors like himself.

The gardens were Mrs. Pemberton's pride and joy, though her arthritis had made it increasingly difficult for her to maintain them properly. That's where Maya came in. Jake's breath caught slightly as he spotted her familiar figure moving between the rose bushes, her dark hair pulled back in a practical ponytail as she worked. She'd been the estate's gardener for just over a year now, and Jake had spent most of that time trying to convince himself that his growing feelings for her were nothing more than loneliness manifesting itself inappropriately.

It wasn't working very well.

Maya Thornfield had arrived at the estate on a rainy Tuesday morning, her ancient Land Rover packed with tools and an impressive collection of seedlings. She was twenty-six, two years younger than Jake, with callused hands that spoke of honest work and green eyes that seemed to see straight through his carefully constructed facade. Within weeks, she had transformed the neglected flower beds into something approaching their former glory, coaxing life from soil that had seemed barren and hopeless.

Jake pulled on his worn jeans and a faded t-shirt, running his fingers through his unruly brown hair before making his way downstairs. Mrs. Pemberton was already in the kitchen, humming tunelessly as she prepared her morning tea. At seventy-eight, she moved with the deliberate care of someone who had learned not to take physical stability for granted, but her mind remained sharp as ever.

"Morning, dear," she said without turning around. "Maya's been out there since dawn. That girl works too hard."

"Good morning, Mrs. P." Jake accepted the mug of coffee she handed him gratefully. "I'll take her some tea in a bit."

The older woman gave him a knowing look. "Will you now? How thoughtful of you."

Jake felt heat rise in his cheeks. His feelings for Maya weren't exactly subtle, despite his best efforts. Even without the Force, it would have been obvious to anyone paying attention. Mrs. Pemberton was definitely paying attention.

"She needs to stay hydrated," he mumbled into his coffee mug.

"Of course she does." Mrs. Pemberton's eyes twinkled with amusement. "You know, Jake, there's nothing wrong with admitting you fancy someone. You're both adults, and you're both single. Unless there's something you haven't told me about your mysterious past?"

There were many things Jake hadn't told her about his mysterious past, but none of them involved romantic entanglements. The Jedi Order had fallen before he'd had much chance to grapple with questions of love and attachment, though he suspected his old Master would have had strong opinions on the subject. Master Kellan had been traditional in his interpretation of the Jedi Code, viewing emotional attachments as pathways to the dark side.

But Master Kellan was dead now, cut down during Order 66 along with so many others. The Code felt like ancient history, a relic of a time when there had been thousands of Jedi to uphold its principles. Now there was just Jake, hiding in an English garden and falling helplessly in love with a woman who thought he was nothing more than Mrs. Pemberton's odd handyman.

"Nothing like that," he said finally. "I just... it's complicated."

"Most worthwhile things are." Mrs. Pemberton patted his shoulder gently. "But don't let complicated become an excuse for cowardice, dear. Life's too short and unpredictable for that."

Jake nodded, though he wasn't sure he agreed. In his experience, life was often too long and too predictable, especially when you were trying to avoid the attention of Imperial forces. Still, he found himself preparing a tray with tea and biscuits for Maya, telling himself it was simple courtesy rather than an excuse to spend time with her.

The morning air was crisp with the promise of autumn as Jake made his way through the garden paths. Maya was kneeling beside a bed of late-blooming chrysanthemums, carefully removing spent flowers with a pair of small pruning shears. She looked up as he approached, pushing a strand of hair away from her face with the back of her gardening glove.

"You're an angel," she said, accepting the steaming mug gratefully. "I was just thinking I could murder a cup of tea."

"Mrs. P's orders," Jake lied easily. "She thinks you work too hard."

"Mrs. P is probably right." Maya settled back on her heels, cradling the mug in both hands. "But these flowers won't deadhead themselves, and we're supposed to get frost next week. I want to give them every chance to keep blooming."

Jake crouched down beside her, close enough to catch the faint scent of her shampoo mixed with earth and green growing things. "Need help?"

"Always." Maya handed him a spare pair of shears. "Just cut above the next set of healthy leaves. These chrysanthemums can be quite prolific if you treat them right."

They worked in comfortable silence for a while, their hands occasionally brushing as they reached for the same stem. Jake found himself hyperaware of her presence beside him, the quiet concentration on her face as she worked, the way she unconsciously bit her lower lip when she encountered a particularly stubborn flower. Through the Force, he could sense her contentment, the deep satisfaction she found in nurturing growing things.

It was one of the things he loved most about her, though he'd never admitted it aloud. Maya had a gift for bringing life and beauty to neglected spaces. She saw potential where others saw only decay, and she wasn't afraid of the patient work required to realize that potential. In many ways, she reminded Jake of the best aspects of the Jedi philosophy he'd been raised with, though she'd never held a lightsaber or meditated on the nature of the Force.

"Jake?" Maya's voice interrupted his reverie. "Can I ask you something?"

"Of course."

"Where did you learn to garden? I mean, you're quite good at this, but you never talk about where you picked it up."

Jake's hands stilled on the chrysanthemum stems. It was a reasonable question, the sort of casual inquiry that arose naturally between people who worked closely together. The problem was that his gardening skills, like most of his practical knowledge, came from his Jedi training. The Temple on Coruscant had maintained extensive gardens, and young Padawans were expected to spend time learning to cultivate and care for living things. Master Kellan had always said that understanding life was essential to understanding the Force.

"My... my father taught me," he said finally, which wasn't entirely untrue. The Jedi who had raised him had been the closest thing to a father he'd ever known. "He believed that working with plants taught patience and respect for living things."

"He sounds like a wise man." Maya resumed her pruning. "Is he still alive?"

The familiar ache of loss tightened in Jake's chest. "No. He died several years ago."

"I'm sorry." Maya's voice was soft with genuine sympathy. "You don't talk about your family much."

"There isn't much to say. It's just me now."

Maya glanced at him sideways, and Jake sensed her curiosity warring with respect for his obvious reluctance to discuss his past. It was a dance they'd performed many times over the past year, Maya gently probing and Jake deflecting with vague half-truths that satisfied her surface curiosity without revealing anything meaningful about who he really was or where he'd come from.

He hated lying to her, but the alternative was unthinkable. How could he possibly explain that he was a survivor of a religious order that most people now believed had been a corrupt institution justly destroyed by the Empire? How could he tell her that he carried a weapon capable of cutting through steel, that he could move objects with his mind, that he sometimes woke in the night with visions of distant suffering echoing through the Force? Maya lived in a world of soil and seasons, of practical problems with practical solutions. The galaxy's larger conflicts seemed mercifully distant from this quiet corner of Surrey, and Jake was determined to keep it that way.

"We all have our secrets, I suppose," Maya said eventually, her tone carefully neutral. She moved to the next cluster of flowers, and Jake followed, grateful that she wasn't pressing the issue. "Mrs. Pemberton mentioned that you help her with repairs around the estate. Are you handy with mechanical things too?"

Jake nodded, relieved by the change of subject. "I can usually figure out what's wrong with most machinery. It's just a matter of understanding how the pieces fit together." This was true enough, though he carefully didn't mention that the Force often guided his understanding, showing him the flow of energy through circuits and gears in ways that purely technical training never could have achieved.

"Well, if you ever get tired of fixing gutters and painting fences, I could use someone to look at the mower. It's been making terrible noises, and I'm afraid it's going to give up the ghost entirely." Maya stood and stretched, brushing dirt from the knees of her practical canvas trousers. "Though I suppose you'd rather not spend your free time doing more manual labor."

"I don't mind," Jake said quickly. "I mean, I enjoy working with my hands. And it's not as if I have pressing social obligations." The last part came out more bitter than he'd intended, and Maya raised an eyebrow at his tone.

"You could, you know. Have social obligations. There's a perfectly decent pub in the village, and Mrs. Pemberton says the local amateur dramatics society is always looking for new members." Maya's green eyes held a hint of challenge. "Unless you're one of those mysterious loners who's too good for small-town entertainment."

Jake felt a smile tug at the corners of his mouth despite himself. Maya had a talent for gentle teasing that somehow managed to be affectionate rather than cruel. It was another thing he'd added to his growing list of reasons why he was falling in love with her, though he tried not to dwell on that particular revelation too closely.

"I'm not too good for anything," he said. "I just prefer quiet evenings. All that socializing can be... overwhelming." This was perhaps the most honest thing he'd said to her in months. Large crowds made him nervous in ways that had nothing to do with shyness and everything to do with the increased chance of recognition by Imperial agents or bounty hunters. Even in peaceful Surrey, Jake had never quite managed to shake the hypervigilance that had kept him alive for three years of hiding.

"Fair enough," Maya said, though something in her expression suggested she wasn't entirely satisfied with his explanation. "But you might consider giving the pub a try sometime. The Lamb and Flag does excellent fish and chips on Fridays, and the locals are friendly enough once they get used to you. You've been here three years, Jake. At some point, you're going to have to decide whether you're hiding from something or just hiding from life."

The observation hit uncomfortably close to home, and Jake found himself looking away from Maya's perceptive gaze. She was right, of course, though not in the way she imagined. He was hiding from something very specific and very dangerous, but somewhere along the way, that necessary caution had expanded into a more general withdrawal from human connection. It was safer to keep people at arm's length, to maintain the polite distance that would allow him to disappear quickly if the need arose.

But Maya was making it increasingly difficult to maintain that distance. She had a way of slipping past his defenses with casual observations and genuine interest in his wellbeing. She remembered things he mentioned in passing, brought him soup when he'd been fighting off a cold, and had somehow convinced Mrs. Pemberton to let her plant a small herb garden outside his loft window because she'd noticed how much he enjoyed cooking. These small kindnesses accumulated like interest, creating a debt of affection that Jake wasn't sure he could repay without compromising the careful anonymity that had kept him safe.

"Maybe you're right," he said finally, which was about as much of a concession as he was prepared to make. "I'll think about it."

Maya's smile was warm and encouraging, and Jake felt something flutter in his chest that had nothing to do with the Force and everything to do with the way the morning light caught the gold flecks in her green eyes. He was in serious trouble, he realized, and not the sort that could be solved with a lightsaber or a quick escape to the next system. This was the kind of trouble that required difficult choices and emotional honesty, two things that Jake had been avoiding with determined consistency since arriving at Mrs. Pemberton's estate.

The sound of tires on gravel interrupted his brooding, and both Jake and Maya turned toward the front of the house where an unfamiliar black sedan was pulling up the circular drive. Jake's hand moved instinctively toward where his lightsaber would have hung if he'd been wearing it, then forced himself to relax. Visitors weren't necessarily threats, despite what three years of paranoia had trained him to believe.

"Expecting someone?" Maya asked Mrs. Pemberton, who had emerged from the house to greet the new arrivals.

"Not that I recall," the elderly woman replied, though her tone was curious rather than concerned. "Perhaps it's someone inquiring about the cottage rental advertisement."

Jake tensed. Mrs. Pemberton had mentioned placing an advertisement for the small guest cottage at the far end of the property, hoping to generate a bit of additional income now that the estate's maintenance costs were rising. The idea of strangers living so close to his hiding place made Jake profoundly uncomfortable, but he could hardly object without explaining why he was so concerned about privacy and security.

Two men emerged from the sedan, both wearing dark suits that seemed impractical for the rural Surrey setting. They moved with the kind of controlled precision that Jake recognized from his years of military training, their eyes constantly scanning their surroundings in a way that suggested professional paranoia rather than casual curiosity. Jake's mouth went dry as he recognized the signs of trained operatives, though he couldn't immediately determine whether they were Imperial agents, bounty hunters, or representatives of some other organization entirely.

"Mrs. Pemberton?" The taller of the two men approached with a polite smile that didn't quite reach his eyes. "I'm Agent Morrison from the Ministry of Defence. This is my colleague, Agent Webb. We were wondering if we might have a word with you about a security matter."

**Chapter 2**

The blood in Jake's veins turned to ice water as the word 'security' hung in the morning air like a death sentence. Every instinct screamed at him to run, to grab his lightsaber from its hiding place and disappear into the Surrey countryside before these agents could complete whatever mission had brought them to Mrs. Pemberton's peaceful estate. His hand trembled slightly as he forced himself to continue deadheading chrysanthemums, maintaining the facade of a simple gardener's assistant while his mind raced through escape routes and contingency plans he'd hoped never to use.

Maya seemed to sense his sudden tension, glancing at him with a puzzled frown before turning her attention back to the unfolding scene near the house. Mrs. Pemberton appeared unruffled by the unexpected visit, inviting the agents inside with the same gracious hospitality she showed to everyone who crossed her threshold. Jake watched helplessly as the three figures disappeared through the front door, leaving him alone in the garden with Maya and a growing sense of impending doom.

"That was odd," Maya observed, settling back on her heels beside the flower bed. "Ministry of Defence agents don't usually make house calls in Surrey, do they? Mrs. P isn't exactly the sort of person you'd expect to be involved in matters of national security." She paused, studying Jake's face with the same careful attention she gave to ailing plants. "You've gone completely white. Are you feeling alright?"

Jake realized he was hyperventilating and forced himself to take slow, measured breaths. Through the Force, he could sense the agents' presence inside the house like cold spots in the warm tapestry of the estate's usual emotional landscape. They radiated the kind of controlled aggression that spoke of men accustomed to violence, though their intentions remained frustratingly opaque. He couldn't determine whether they were specifically hunting for him or if this visit was related to some other matter entirely, but either way, his carefully constructed sanctuary was now compromised.

"I'm fine," he managed, though his voice sounded strained even to his own ears. "Just surprised, I suppose. You don't expect government agents to show up at a quiet country estate." He stood abruptly, scattering chrysanthemum clippings from his lap. "I should check on Mrs. P. Make sure she doesn't need anything."

Maya caught his wrist as he started toward the house, her gardening glove warm against his skin. "Jake, what aren't you telling me? You look like you've seen a ghost, and don't say it's just surprise. I've known you for over a year, and I've never seen you react like this to anything." Her green eyes searched his face with uncomfortable intensity. "Are you in some kind of trouble?"

The question hung between them like a bridge Jake could either cross or burn, and for a moment he was tempted to tell her everything. The loneliness of carrying his secrets alone had been wearing on him more heavily than he'd realized, and the genuine concern in Maya's voice made him want to trust her with truths he'd never spoken aloud. She deserved better than the careful lies he'd been feeding her, deserved to know that the man she'd been working beside for months was not the simple handyman he pretended to be.

But the sound of voices from the house reminded him sharply of the dangers such honesty would bring. If these agents were indeed hunting for surviving Jedi, then Maya's ignorance was her protection. The Empire had demonstrated repeatedly that it was willing to eliminate anyone who aided or harbored fugitives from Imperial justice, and Jake would not make Maya a target through misguided confessions. Better to maintain the deception that kept her safe, even if it meant continuing to lie to the woman he was falling in love with.

"Everyone has things in their past they'd rather not discuss," he said carefully, gently extracting his wrist from her grip. "I'm just not fond of authority figures asking questions. Bad experiences with bureaucracy." It was a weak explanation, but it was all he could offer without revealing more than was safe. "I'll be back in a few minutes."

Maya's expression suggested she wasn't satisfied with his evasion, but she nodded reluctantly and returned to her pruning. Jake could feel her worried gaze following him as he made his way toward the house, moving with what he hoped appeared to be casual concern rather than desperate panic. Through the diamond-paned windows of the sitting room, he could see Mrs. Pemberton seated in her favorite armchair while the two agents occupied the sofa across from her, their postures suggesting polite interrogation rather than social conversation.

Jake positioned himself near the kitchen window that looked into the sitting room, close enough to overhear the conversation without being obvious about his eavesdropping. Mrs. Pemberton was speaking in her usual calm, measured tones, though Jake could detect a slight stiffness in her manner that suggested she was not entirely comfortable with her visitors.

"As I mentioned, gentlemen, my late husband did serve in the Royal Navy, but that was decades ago. I can't imagine what relevance his service record might have to current security concerns." Mrs. Pemberton's voice carried the faint edge of aristocratic authority that she rarely displayed but which reminded listeners that she had not always been a country widow of modest means. "He passed away eight years ago, and took most of his military memories with him."

Agent Morrison consulted a small notebook, his movements precise and economical. "We're actually more interested in your current household, Mrs. Pemberton. Our records indicate that you've taken in a lodger in recent years, a young man named Jake Meridian. We'd very much like to speak with him about a matter of mutual interest."

Jake's blood turned to ice as his assumed name left the agent's lips. The false identity he'd constructed so carefully had somehow attracted official attention, which meant either his documentation was less perfect than he'd believed or someone had connected him to his Jedi past despite his precautions. Either possibility represented a catastrophic failure of the security measures that had kept him alive for three years of hiding.

Mrs. Pemberton's response was delayed by just long enough to suggest she was choosing her words carefully. "Jake is indeed staying in the converted stable loft, and has been for some time. He's been tremendously helpful with maintenance around the estate, though I know very little about his background. He's quite private about personal matters." She paused, and Jake could practically hear her internal debate about how much information to volunteer. "May I ask what sort of mutual interest you're referring to? Jake seems like a perfectly ordinary young man to me."

Agent Webb leaned forward slightly, his voice taking on a tone of practiced reassurance. "Nothing alarming, I assure you. We simply have reason to believe that Mr. Meridian might possess information relevant to an ongoing investigation. Historical information, you might say, about events that occurred several years ago. We're hoping he might be willing to assist with our inquiries."

The euphemistic language did nothing to disguise the threat implicit in the agents' words, and Jake felt the familiar weight of the Force pressing against his consciousness as his emotional state became increasingly unstable. Somewhere in the garden behind him, a ceramic flowerpot cracked audibly, though he hoped the sound was too distant for the agents to notice. He needed to get control of himself before his unconscious use of the Force provided these men with exactly the evidence they were seeking.

Mrs. Pemberton's voice took on a protective edge that made Jake's chest tighten with unexpected emotion. "I see. And if Jake chooses not to assist with these inquiries of yours? I assume his cooperation is voluntary?" The question carried implications that were not lost on anyone present, and Jake realized with a mixture of gratitude and alarm that Mrs. Pemberton understood more about the nature of this visit than she was letting on.

"Of course," Agent Morrison replied smoothly, though his tone suggested that voluntary cooperation was strongly preferred over the alternatives. "We're simply hoping to have a conversation with him. Perhaps you could let him know that we stopped by? We'll be staying at the Lamb and Flag in the village for the next few days, in case he decides he'd like to speak with us."

Jake felt his world shifting beneath his feet as the agents rose to leave, their polite farewells masking what amounted to a veiled ultimatum. They knew where he lived, they knew his assumed identity, and they would be waiting in the village for him to either surrender voluntarily or force them to take more direct action. Either way, his time at Mrs. Pemberton's estate was over, and the life he'd built here was about to collapse around him.

He moved quickly away from the window as footsteps approached the front door, retreating toward the garden where Maya was still working among the flowers. She looked up as he rejoined her, her expression immediately concerned as she took in what must have been his obvious distress.

"What did they want?" she asked quietly, setting down her pruning shears and giving him her full attention. "And don't tell me it was routine government business, because you look like someone just walked over your grave."

Jake sank down beside her on the grass, his legs suddenly unsteady. Through the Force, he could sense the agents' departure, their black sedan pulling away from the estate with measured deliberation. They weren't in any hurry because they knew he had nowhere to run, at least not without abandoning everything and everyone he'd come to care about in Surrey. It was a masterfully executed psychological trap, offering him just enough time to contemplate what he would be losing before forcing him to make an impossible choice.

"They were asking about me," he said finally, the words feeling like broken glass in his throat. "They want to talk to me about something that happened years ago, before I came here. They're staying at the pub in the village." He met Maya's eyes, trying to memorize the way the morning light brought out the gold flecks in the green. "I think I'm going to have to leave."

Maya's face went through several expressions in quick succession - confusion, concern, and finally a kind of hurt realization. "Leave? Just like that? Because some government agents want to ask you questions?" She reached for his hand, her fingers intertwining with his despite the dirt under both their nails. "Jake, whatever happened in your past, surely it can't be so bad that you have to run away from it forever. Maybe if you just talked to them, explained your side of things..."

The innocent faith in her voice nearly broke Jake's heart. Maya lived in a world where problems could be solved through honest communication and good intentions, where authority figures were generally trustworthy and the system ultimately fair. She had no frame of reference for the kind of systematic persecution that had driven Jake into hiding, no understanding of how quickly cooperation with the wrong people could lead to imprisonment or death.

"It's not that simple," he said, his thumb tracing across her knuckles in what might be the last intimate gesture he'd ever share with her. "Some things can't be explained or reasoned away. Some people won't listen to explanations even if you offer them." He paused, struggling with how much truth he could afford to share. "I've been running from this for a long time, Maya. I thought I could stop running, thought I could build something here, but I was fooling myself."

Maya's grip on his hand tightened, and Jake could sense her confusion and growing fear through their physical connection. She was beginning to understand that this was not a minor crisis that could be resolved with a difficult conversation, but rather something that threatened to tear away the life they'd both been building on the estate.

"What did you do?" she asked quietly, and Jake heard no judgment in the question, only a desperate need to understand. "What could possibly be so terrible that you've spent years hiding from it?"

Jake opened his mouth to answer, then closed it again as he realized there were no words that could bridge the gap between Maya's world and his own. How could he explain that he had been trained from childhood to serve a cause that the galaxy now viewed as treasonous? How could he make her understand that his very existence was considered a threat to Imperial stability, that the peaceful life they'd shared was built on foundations of deception and constant vigilance?

The sound of Mrs. Pemberton's voice calling from the house provided a merciful interruption, though Jake suspected the elderly woman's timing was not entirely coincidental. She had probably been watching from the windows, giving him and Maya privacy for their conversation while ensuring she could intervene before things became too difficult to manage.

"I should go talk to her," Jake said, reluctantly releasing Maya's hand and getting to his feet. "She deserves to know what's happening, and I need to make sure she'll be safe after I'm gone." He looked down at Maya, who was still kneeling among the chrysanthemums with tears threatening at the corners of her eyes. "We'll talk more later, I promise. But right now I need to figure out how to protect the people I care about."

Maya nodded wordlessly, and Jake could feel her watching him as he walked back toward the house. Mrs. Pemberton was waiting in the kitchen, her face grave but unsurprised by the turn of events. She gestured for him to sit at the small table where they'd shared so many morning conversations over the past three years, then put the kettle on for tea with the automatic motions of someone who had weathered many crises with the aid of proper refreshments.

"Those men weren't really from the Ministry of Defence," she said without preamble, settling into the chair across from him. "Oh, they had the right credentials and the proper manner, but there was something off about them. Too smooth, too rehearsed. Like actors playing roles they'd memorized but not internalized." She studied Jake's face with the same sharp intelligence that had first convinced him she could be trusted. "The question is, who are they really, and what do they want with my Jake?"

The possessive pronoun hit Jake harder than he'd expected, and he felt his throat tighten with emotion. Mrs. Pemberton had given him more than just shelter over the past three years; she had given him a sense of belonging that he hadn't experienced since the fall of the Jedi Temple. The idea of repaying her kindness by bringing danger to her doorstep was almost unbearable.

"They're probably exactly who they claim to be," he said carefully. "Government agents investigating something from my past. The problem is that what they're investigating isn't something I can discuss openly, and cooperation with their inquiry would put both of us in danger." He met her eyes, trying to convey sincerity without revealing specifics. "I never meant for this to follow me here, Mrs. P. I thought I'd been careful enough, but apparently I was wrong."

Mrs. Pemberton poured boiling water into the teapot and let it steep, her movements deliberate and calming. "You know, my dear, I may be an old woman living quietly in the country, but I'm not entirely naive about the way the world works. These were not merely well-meaning amateurs willing to risk everything for abstract principles, but trained operatives who understood the logistics and strategic implications of extracting high-value targets from Imperial custody. Their presence suggested connections to organized resistance movements that possessed resources and intelligence networks far more sophisticated than Jake had imagined possible given the Empire's systematic efforts to eliminate all opposition to their authority. The realization that his personal choice of peaceful exile had been monitored and protected by people whose existence he had never suspected was both humbling and deeply unsettling.

Kallus had retreated to a position behind his command vehicle as the tactical situation deteriorated beyond his ability to salvage through conventional Imperial doctrine and overwhelming firepower. Jake could sense the agent's growing desperation as his carefully planned operation dissolved into exactly the kind of public confrontation that would require extensive explanations to superiors who measured success by clean operations and minimal complications. The presence of two active Jedi Knights operating in coordination with organized resistance cells represented the kind of intelligence failure that ended careers and sometimes resulted in more permanent consequences for Imperial officers who disappointed their ruthless superiors. Kallus was no longer simply pursuing fugitives; he was fighting for his own survival within a system that tolerated failure only when it served larger strategic objectives.

The sound of TIE fighter engines grew louder as Imperial aerial support prepared to strafe the estate grounds regardless of friendly fire casualties among their own ground forces, a doctrine of overwhelming destructive response that prioritized mission completion over personnel preservation. Jake realized that they had perhaps minutes before the approaching aircraft would transform the battlefield into a killing field where survival depended on immediate evacuation rather than tactical superiority or heroic resistance. The time for fighting their way out of the encirclement was ending, replaced by the more urgent necessity of coordinated withdrawal before Imperial reinforcements made any escape attempt impossible.

Kira appeared beside him with the sudden silence that marked advanced Force techniques, her approach unnoticed by Imperial forces despite the chaos of battle raging around them. Her face showed the wear of three years spent in constant motion and perpetual danger, but her eyes blazed with the same determined idealism that had characterized her personality during their shared apprenticeship under Master Kellan's guidance. The sight of her alive and still fighting against impossible odds filled Jake with a mixture of joy and guilt, happiness at their reunion balanced against shame for his own withdrawal from active resistance while she had continued carrying the burden of their shared heritage and responsibilities.

The old Jake Voss would have recognized the wisdom of leaving civilians behind to ensure the success of military operations against Imperial forces, understanding that individual lives had to be weighed against larger strategic objectives in any meaningful resistance movement. But the man who had learned to love Maya's laugh and treasure Mrs. Pemberton's quiet wisdom could not conceive of purchasing his own freedom with their suffering, even if their capture would serve the greater good by allowing him to rejoin the fight against Imperial tyranny.
